row.project_abstract: In the 1920s, Paul Jay Adams led several expeditions to the summit of Mount Le Conte, which is widely regarded as the "crown jewel" of the Great Smoky Mountains. From 1925 to 1926, Adams operated a camp on Mount Le Conte, near the site of the present day Le Conte Lodge. During those years, Adams was accompanied by a German shepherd named "Cumberland Jack." Adams and Cumberland Jack remained at the camp until May 10, 1926, when Jack Huff took over its management. The Ilene Jones Cornwell Papers, MS.2054, in the University of Tennessee Libraries Special Collections contain a number of photographs from Adams's expeditions during those years. These rare photos provide a unique glimpse into one of the earliest camps built on Mount Le Conte.
row.subject_geographic: Great Smoky Mountains (N.C. and Tenn.) | URI: http://id.loc.gov/authorities/subjects/sh85057008 | Coordinates: 35.58343, -83.50822
row.abstract: Adams occupied this camp on Mount Le Conte, which consisted of a tar-paper covered lean-to north of Cliff Top, in 1925.
row.public_note: "padams8" written in pencil on back of photo.
Date inferred from archival collection dates.
row.title: Tar-paper shack of Mt. LeConte where first two Park Commissioners Parties stayed, built in 1924
row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.
row.repository: University of Tennessee, Knoxville. Special Collections
row.name: Unknown | Role: Creator | Role URI: http://id.loc.gov/vocabulary/relators/cre

row.project_abstract: In the 1920s, Paul Jay Adams led several expeditions to the summit of Mount Le Conte, which is widely regarded as the "crown jewel" of the Great Smoky Mountains. From 1925 to 1926, Adams operated a camp on Mount Le Conte, near the site of the present day Le Conte Lodge. During those years, Adams was accompanied by a German shepherd named "Cumberland Jack." Adams and Cumberland Jack remained at the camp until May 10, 1926, when Jack Huff took over its management. The Ilene Jones Cornwell Papers, MS.2054, in the University of Tennessee Libraries Special Collections contain a number of photographs from Adams's expeditions during those years. These rare photos provide a unique glimpse into one of the earliest camps built on Mount Le Conte.
row.subject_geographic: Great Smoky Mountains (N.C. and Tenn.) | URI: http://id.loc.gov/authorities/subjects/sh85057008 | Coordinates: 35.58343, -83.50822
row.public_note: "padams28" written in pencil on back of photo.
row.title: Thompson Photography employees at Basin Spring Camp, Mt. LeConte, picture taken in 1926 (summer)
row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.

row.project_abstract: In the 1920s, Paul Jay Adams led several expeditions to the summit of Mount Le Conte, which is widely regarded as the "crown jewel" of the Great Smoky Mountains. From 1925 to 1926, Adams operated a camp on Mount Le Conte, near the site of the present day Le Conte Lodge. During those years, Adams was accompanied by a German shepherd named "Cumberland Jack." Adams and Cumberland Jack remained at the camp until May 10, 1926, when Jack Huff took over its management. The Ilene Jones Cornwell Papers, MS.2054, in the University of Tennessee Libraries Special Collections contain a number of photographs from Adams's expeditions during those years. These rare photos provide a unique glimpse into one of the earliest camps built on Mount Le Conte.
row.subject_geographic: Great Smoky Mountains (N.C. and Tenn.) | URI: http://id.loc.gov/authorities/subjects/sh85057008 | Coordinates: 35.58343, -83.50822
row.abstract: Adams hiked Mt. Le Conte in July 1975 to mark the 50th anniversary of the camp he had established there. This was likely Adams's last hike up Le Conte; he died in 1985.
row.public_note: "padams23" (3) (people) p. 6 written on back of photo.
row.title: 7/14/75 Picture of Paul J. Adams Old Lodge top of Mt. Le Conte made by Mrs. Arnold C. Moore, Atlanta, Ga.
row.rights: The copyright interests in this item remain with the creator. For more information, contact Special Collections at special@utk.edu.

row.project_abstract: In the 1920s, Paul Jay Adams led several expeditions to the summit of Mount Le Conte, which is widely regarded as the "crown jewel" of the Great Smoky Mountains. From 1925 to 1926, Adams operated a camp on Mount Le Conte, near the site of the present day Le Conte Lodge. During those years, Adams was accompanied by a German shepherd named "Cumberland Jack." Adams and Cumberland Jack remained at the camp until May 10, 1926, when Jack Huff took over its management. The Ilene Jones Cornwell Papers, MS.2054, in the University of Tennessee Libraries Special Collections contain a number of photographs from Adams's expeditions during those years. These rare photos provide a unique glimpse into one of the earliest camps built on Mount Le Conte.
row.subject_geographic: Great Smoky Mountains (N.C. and Tenn.) | URI: http://id.loc.gov/authorities/subjects/sh85057008 | Coordinates: 35.58343, -83.50822
row.abstract: Adams operated his camp until May 10, 1926 when Jack Huff and Will Ramsay took over management. Huff began construction on a new cabin - "The House that Jack Built" (visible on the right).
row.public_note: "padams12" written in pencil on back of photo.
row.title: Basin Spring Camp 1926, Adams Cabin on left, Huff Cabin on Right.
